title: EUROPE MARKETS: European Markets Rise; Investors Wait For QE Hints From Draghi
text:
By Carla Mozee, MarketWatch
European stocks popped higher Thursday, with investors waiting for a signal that the European Central Bank may be considering pumping more stimulus into the eurozone economy.
The Stoxx Europe 600 rose 1.3% to 358.46. All sectors gained ground, led by the technology, health care and basic materials sectors.
In the health care group, Novartis AG (NOVN.VX) shares tacked on 2% after the pharmaceutical company said it will start selling a copycat version (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/novartis-to-begin-selling-neupogen-copy-in-us-2015-09-03) of Amgen Inc.'s (AMGN) blockbuster cancer drug Neupogen.
Among country indexes, Germany's DAX 30 was up 1.7% to 10,213.69, France's CAC 30 moved up 1.2% to 4,608.01, and Spain's IBEX 35 gained 0.5% to 9,988.90. In London, the FTSE 100 rose 1.4% to 6,165.44.
Equities held to higher ground after Markit's eurozone services PMI for August came in at 54.4 (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/eurozone-economy-grows-faster-than-expected-2015-09-03) in its final reading, higher than the initial, or flash, estimate of 54.3. The volatile Chinese markets, which have swayed global markets, are closed for two days for a holiday (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/china-to-close-stock-market-to-honor-world-war-ii-anniversary-2015-09-01).
ECB: Thursday's main event for the markets is ECB President Mario Draghi's press conference on the central bank's latest policy decision at 1:30 p.m. London time, or 8:30 a.m. Eastern Time. The ECB left interest rates unchanged (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/ecb-leaves-rates-unchanged-draghi-in-focus-2015-09-03), as expected.
Read: 5 things to watch at Thursday's ECB meeting (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/5-things-to-watch-at-thursdays-ecb-meeting-2015-09-02).
Investors will look for any sign from Draghi that the ECB is on course to extend or expand measures aimed at bolstering inflation levels and boosting the eurozone economy, as fears linger about slowing global growth led by China. The impact of plunging commodity prices may also play a role in the ECB's staff projections for the economic growth and inflation.
"Although we expect no policy change from the ECB this week, the implicit tightening of monetary conditions through the 3% rise in [the euro trade-weighted index] since the last meeting should keep the tone dovish" and negative for the euro, said Keng Goh, associate FX strategist at RBC Capital Markets, in a note.
The "turmoil in emerging markets, collapsing inflation expectations and continued uncertainty in Greece all should encourage the ECB to maintain a steady hand," said Goh.
The euro was trading at $1.1231 versus $1.1240 late Wednesday in New York.
(http://www.marketwatch.com/story/5-things-to-watch-at-thursdays-ecb-meeting-2015-09-02)Movers: Syngenta AG (SYNN.VX) shares jumped 3.1% as the pesticides seller said it will sell its global vegetable-seed business and return more than $2 billion to shareholders (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/syngenta-to-sell-unit-plans-2-billion-buyback-2015-09-03).
EasyJet PLC (EZJ.LN) shares soared 5.4% after the budget airline raised its fiscal 2015 pretax profit forecast (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/easyjet-lifts-outlook-following-strong-summer-2015-09-03) after a strong summer season.
Vivendi SA (VIV.FR) shares gave up earlier gains to slip 0.1%. The media company posted a 32% gain (http://www.wsj.com/articles/vivendi-earnings-rise-1441212047) in second-quarter profit, boosted by the sale of its Brazilian telecoms unit.
